# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text, ' ')
    result = ""
    temp = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(temp) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            result *= temp * "\n"
            temp = word
        else
            if length(temp) > 0
                temp *= " "
            end
            temp *= word
        end
    end
    
    if length(temp) > 0
        result *= temp
    end
    
    return result
end

println(wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines"))
```

When you run this code, it will output:
```
This function will
wrap words into
lines
```
This means we have a line that follows the maximum text width of `10`. If the current word when added to the current line word would extend a line beyond `text_width`, the current line is added to `result` and a new line is started with the word.  This prevents words that are longer than `text_width` from continuing over multiple lines.
